text: I am in the process of thinking about podcasting for work. I think I am going to lean pretty heavily into transcripts and utilizing those along with a short intro into what was discussed and the guest we will have on the show. I like what transcripts can do for SEO and making the podcast and all the information we’ll be gathering much more accessible to those who can’t listen or don’t have time to listen. Plus transcripts are so cheap to get these days and really high-quality so I want to use the transcripts however I can.

text: I basically do a summary of my episodes but add in screenshots of things i discussed (most of my episodes involve a tutorial of sorts).

text: +2 to Ross and Foundation Inc! I’d also second that we also have a list of channels that we go through to see if the piece of content is a good fit for that channel. I usually keep this in a spreadsheet, and group channels by things like “Owned” (organic social, partner program, etc.), “Paid” (PPC, newsletter sponsorship, podcast promotion, native ads, etc.), “Email” (nurtures, standalone promo emails), “Content Syndication / Community” (Zest, GrowthHackers, etc.). Then beside each I have the owner of that specific channel so I know who I need to loop in ahead of time.

elements.text: +2 to Ross and Foundation Inc! I’d also second that we also have a list of channels that we go through to see if the piece of content is a good fit for that channel. text: Any SEO specialists here who can help me understand the pros and cons of choosing a subdomain vs an entirely separate domain for a microsite dedicated to a distinct arm of our company?

elements.text: Any SEO specialists here who can help me understand the pros and cons of choosing a subdomain vs an entirely separate domain for a microsite dedicated to a distinct arm of our company?

text: Generally a subdomain will offer some SEO upside piggybacking off the parent domain for backlink/authority value, where a separate domain would effectively start from square one. It (likely) wouldn't have direct brand association by being on the primary domain, and wouldn't have any backlink authority from other websites linking to the domain. That's generally the core of the conversation.

elements.text: Generally a subdomain will offer some SEO upside piggybacking off the parent domain for backlink/authority value, where a separate domain would effectively start from square one. It (likely) wouldn't have direct brand association by being on the primary domain, and wouldn't have any backlink authority from other websites linking to the domain. That's generally the core of the conversation.

text: You can generally design, host, and interlink things however you want in either setup. So that becomes a moot point. If timely ROI from SEO is integral, a subdomain is likely a better bet. If it's a longer time horizon you're working with, sometimes it's own domain can have value-add for being more brandable.

elements.text: You can generally design, host, and interlink things however you want in either setup. So that becomes a moot point. If timely ROI from SEO is integral, a subdomain is likely a better bet. If it's a longer time horizon you're working with, sometimes it's own domain can have value-add for being more brandable.

text: Thank you! I was reading that it was murky as to whether a subdomain actually inherited any authority.

elements.text: Thank you! I was reading that it was murky as to whether a subdomain actually inherited any authority.

text: Yeah, I would encourage leaning in the direction that it does. But it's very testable too. And if it launches on a subdomain and doesn't get traction and a separate domain is preferred -- nothing prevents it from being relocated. So it's a flexible setup. The primary ideal scenario for SEO is if it's launched as a separate directory on the primary domain. (<http://exmaple.com/test|exmaple.com/test> vs <http://test.example.com|test.example.com>).

elements.text: Yeah, I would encourage leaning in the direction that it does. But it's very testable too. vs

text: IMO if you're open to using a subdomain and want SEO value... it should be considered if it can be built on the primary domain as a subfolder unless there's serious technical hangups to it which is the most common reason those things don't happen (different CMS/platforms, resources, etc)

elements.text: IMO if you're open to using a subdomain and want SEO value... it should be considered if it can be built on the primary domain as a subfolder unless there's serious technical hangups to it which is the most common reason those things don't happen (different CMS/platforms, resources, etc)

text: Got it. Yeah, we have the pages built as primary folder now, but there’s a lot of confusion about the overlap between our core product offering (for the masses) and this separate arm (for high net worth audiences) that our HNW sales people are fighting against. So the idea was to build them a separate site with its own nav, etc.

text: Yep, makes sense. Can still do things to interlink the two domains/subdomain and share SEO value between the two, but if they're looking for it to stand on it's own - it has better odds still attached to the core brand's domain from my experience

text:
Question for those managing marketing budgets: How do you gauge what the total size of your  budget should be? I've typically tried to advocate for my budget to be somewhere between 5-15% of company revenue, but this is really just based off reading a few blog posts that said I should do that. Curious how others think about this.

For reference: I'm building a marketing budget for an insuretech company with some investment capital behind it and aggressive growth goals.

elements.text:
Question for those managing marketing budgets: How do you gauge what the total size of your  budget should be? I've typically tried to advocate for my budget to be somewhere between 5-15% of company revenue, but this is really just based off reading a few blog posts that said I should do that. Curious how others think about this.

For reference: I'm building a marketing budget for an insuretech company with some investment capital behind it and aggressive growth goals.

text:
I'd probably drill down more by business type - Seed Stage SaaS vs bootstrapped eCommerce vs enterprise tech vs SMB, etc.

Going to be a big difference in gross margins between service business and SaaS for instance.

Once you drill down that way to companies with similar P&L structure I think there's more educated benchmark data available - eg <https://www.bigdropinc.com/blog/how-much-should-your-saas-marketing-budget-be/#:~:text=According%20to%20OpenView's%202017%20Benchmarks,the%20life%20of%20the%20company>.

text:
We try to tie it as much as possible with our goals and we review it every three months. So, if we want to increase paid signups by a X % (which is always our #1 marketing goal) , we look at historical data, seeing what previous activities / pages brought us key page growth so that we actually reach the signup target. Then, we allocate similar resources (mainly in creating new and updating old pages), as well as other activities. We know more or less how much certain activities are going to cost us as we are not starting from scratch, we did them before. An early stage startup for example, will need growth, so investing in new content will be priority. While a more mature company will either have more competitors, so investing in new features, and updating old (or creating new content that tackles issues those new features solve) can be more beneficial.

One of the key things we did in the beginning was invest predominantly in SEO which brought us stable organic traffic of about 10-15k a day. Which is great, as this helps us stay afloat a nd now invest in other channels.

elements.text:
We try to tie it as much as possible with our goals and we review it every three months. So, if we want to increase paid signups by a X % (which is always our #1 marketing goal) , we look at historical data, seeing what previous activities / pages brought us key page growth so that we actually reach the signup target. Then, we allocate similar resources (mainly in creating new and updating old pages), as well as other activities. We know more or less how much certain activities are going to cost us as we are not starting from scratch, we did them before. An early stage startup for example, will need growth, so investing in new content will be priority. While a more mature company will either have more competitors, so investing in new features, and updating old (or creating new content that tackles issues those new features solve) can be more beneficial.

One of the key things we did in the beginning was invest predominantly in SEO which brought us stable organic traffic of about 10-15k a day. Which is great, as this helps us stay afloat a nd now invest in other channels.
